laws.summary: Under Massachusetts law, employers are generally prohibited from asking applicants about their salary history prior to making a job offer with compensation terms.
laws.statute_citation: Massachusetts Equal Pay Act and related wage equity guidance
requirements: Employers may not inquire about or require disclosure of salary history before making an offer of compensation
Applicants may voluntarily disclose salary history without prompting
Employers may consider salary history only after an offer with compensation has been made
Federal anti-discrimination protections also apply

laws.summary: Massachusetts requires covered employers (25+ employees) to disclose the pay range for positions in job postings and to applicants and current employees in certain situations.
laws.statute_citation: An Act Relative to Salary Range Transparency, Mass. Sess. Law ch. 141 (2024)
requirements: Employers with 25 or more employees must include the annual salary range or hourly wage range in all external and internal job postings
Provide the pay range to current employees upon request for their current position
Provide the pay range when offering a promotion or transfer with different job duties
Pay range must be a reasonable, good-faith estimate of what the employer expects to pay at the time of posting
Covered employers with 100+ employees must submit annual EEO/pay data to the Secretary of the Commonwealth

laws.summary: Massachusetts has a statutory regime limiting non-compete covenants. Non-competes are enforceable only under specific statutory conditions.
laws.statute_citation: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 149, § 24L (Noncompetition Agreement Act)
requirements: Non-competes must be in writing and signed by the employee
Employee must receive at least 10 business days’ notice before signing
Must provide consideration (e.g., continued employment) beyond mere employment continuation
Generally limited to 12 months post-employment
Certain categories of employees (e.g., nonexempt under FLSA) cannot be bound by non-competes
Overly broad or statutory non-compliant covenants are unenforceable

laws.summary: Massachusetts does not have a private-sector statewide 'ban-the-box' requirement, but background checks must comply with federal FCRA when using consumer reporting agencies.
requirements: Written consent must be obtained before a third-party background check
Pre-adverse action notice must be provided if information from the report may lead to adverse action
Copy of the report and a summary of rights must be provided
Final adverse action notice must be issued if the decision is made
Use of criminal history must be non-discriminatory
laws.notes: Applicability is triggered when a consumer reporting agency is used.

laws.summary: Massachusetts mandates certain statutory leave rights (e.g., jury duty, voting leave) and has state family and medical leave protections; there is no universal state paid sick leave mandate.
laws.statute_citation: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 149, §§ 52A–52E (Massachusetts Family and Medical Leave); other civil leave statutes
requirements: Employees are entitled to unpaid leave for jury duty without penalty
Employees must be granted time to vote under certain conditions
Massachusetts Family and Medical Leave provides job-protected leave for qualifying medical and family reasons
No general state paid sick leave requirement
laws.notes: Offer letters must not conflict with statutory unpaid leave rights.

laws.summary: Massachusetts allows workplace drug testing; there are limited protections for off-duty cannabis use under state law.
laws.statute_citation: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 94C (marijuana statutes); case law
requirements: Employers may maintain drug-free workplace policies and conduct drug testing
Employers cannot discriminate solely based on off-duty cannabis use where statutory protections apply
Testing protocols should be clear and consistently applied
Policies must comply with applicable state and federal law
laws.notes: Recreational cannabis users have limited employment protections; consult statutory guidance for specifics.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable in Massachusetts if they comply with contract law and are not unconscionable.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; Massachusetts contract law
requirements: Agreement must be voluntary
Must provide clear and mutual obligations
Must not be unconscionable or excessively one-sided
Notice and acceptance should be documented clearly

laws.summary: Massachusetts follows the at-will employment doctrine, subject to exceptions for discrimination, public policy, and implied contract claims.
laws.statute_citation: Massachusetts common law; state anti-discrimination statutes
requirements: Employment is presumed at-will unless a contract specifies otherwise
Employers cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Retaliation for protected activity is unlawful
Employee handbooks and practices may create implied contractual obligations
laws.notes: Clear at-will language in offer letters is recommended.

laws.summary: Massachusetts law prohibits employment discrimination on a broad range of protected characteristics, often providing more expansive protections than federal law.
laws.statute_citation: Massachusetts Fair Employment Practices Laws (e.g., Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 151B)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation
Cannot discriminate based on age (40+), disability, genetic information
Harassment is prohibited
Retaliation for protected activity is unlawful
laws.notes: Offer letters must avoid language implying bias or exclusion.

data_quality.sources: Massachusetts pay transparency statutes, Massachusetts General Laws, official AGO guidance, state earned leave and anti-discrimination codes
data_quality.coverage_completeness: comprehensive for offer-letter and hiring compliance

additional_notes.general_guidance: Massachusetts has recently enacted a comprehensive pay-range transparency law effective October 29, 2025, which must be incorporated in all offer letters and job postings for covered employers. The state also has a structured non-compete regime and robust anti-discrimination protections.
enforcement_agencies: Massachusetts Executive Office of Labor and Workforce Development
recent_developments: Equal Pay and Wage Transparency Acts strengthened statutory hiring obligations
Noncompetete rules tightly regulated under Massachusetts Noncompetition Agreement Act
